summary: the pandemic of H1N1 2009 influenza virus poses a public health threat. worldwide at least 17919 death cases have been reported. the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 has a much higher mortality rate. primers and probes for the novel pandemic H1N1 and the influenza H5N1 were derived from the protocols recommended by WHO [18,19]. the sequence of primers and probes for the novel pandemic H1N1 and the influenza H5N1 were H5-sense: 5'-GGA ACT TAC CAA ATA CTG TCA ATT TCA-3', H5-antisense: 5'-CCA TAA AGA TAG ACC A the duplex real-time RT-PCR amplification was carried out in a 20 L volume reaction with the Quantitect Probe RT-PCR kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) different concentrations of the primers and probes for both H5N1 and H1N1 were combined and adjusted to improve the sensitivity of the assay [20]. 0.4 M of primers and 0.2 M of probe were selected as the optimal concentration for H1 gene. reactions were incubated at 50°C for 30 min, followed by 95°C for 10 min, 45 cycles of 95°C for 15 s, and 52°C for 1 min. fluorescence was recorded at 52°C. the sensitivity of the single real-time RT-PCR assay was 0.2 TCID50 for both novel pandemic H1N1 and H5N1 virus. the detection threshold of the duplex real-time RT-PCR assay was 0.2 TCID50 for the pandemic H1N1 and 0.02 TCID50 for H5N1 virus. a total of 236 clinical throat swab specimens from suspected cases of novel pandemic H1N1 patients were collected. the samples were first detected by WHO real-time RT-PCR protocol for influenza A (H1N1) among the 182 influenza type A positive samples, 124 specimens were positive for the pandemic H1N1 and none for the H5N1 tested by the duplex system. duplex real-time RT-PCR assay for pandemic H1N1 and high pathogenic H5N1 would play an important role for control and prevention of pandemic caused by these viruses.
